issue.title: Label Source feature

repository.name: dffml
repository.description: The easiest way to use Machine Learning. Mix and match underlying ML libraries and data set sources. Generate new datasets or modify existing ones with ease.

issue.body: This PR hopes to add a feature where we can include a label for the data source that can be used to add a version of the data set as well. This will help in having multiple versions of the dataset that can be trained.

issue.title: docs: contributing: git: Add section on contribution requirements

repository.name: dffml
repository.description: The easiest way to use Machine Learning. Mix and match underlying ML libraries and data set sources. Generate new datasets or modify existing ones with ease.

issue.body:
Under `docs/contributing/git.rst` between `Issue and Pull Request title formatting` and `Submitting A Pull Request` we need a section called `Requirements for Contributions`.

It should mention how a change to CHANGELOG.md is required unless you're changing something which was already mentioned in the CHANGELOG since the last release. This is because th epurpose of the CHANGELOG.md file is to tell people what is new *between* releases.

This section would be a good place to put #81

This section should mention that test coverage is expected to increase or stay the same, so tests will be required for almost all contributions.

This sections should mention that documentation is required for any new features. And if you modify the functionality of an existing feature, you're expected to document appropriately.

This section should note that a new plugin should only be added when there is a unique set of new dependencies. For example, if we're adding more Tensorflow models, let's just put it in `model/tensorflow`. Only once you have a new set of dependencies, or the purpose is different enough, then should you create a new plugin. If the feature you're adding has no dependencies on third party libraries (nothing you'd install with `pip`) then it should probably go in `dffml/`, rather than a plugin.
